children.value: Under certain regularity conditions (which we assume), the recursive problem (and its solution) is equivalent to the sequential problem we started with
How does this connect to RL?
(S, A, R) pattern for RL is very closely related to recursive formulation of dynamic programming

children.value: is like repeating (S, A, R) sequence many times
Baseline algorithm for solving DP problem (VFI) is quite similar to how basic RL algorithms work
Start with guess for value, make decision, update guess, repeat...

children.html: p(s′,r∣s,a)=Prob(St+1=s′,Rt+1=r∣St=s,At=1) where ∑s′∈S∑R∈Rp(s′,r∣s,a)=1∀s∈S,a∈A(S) and p(s′,r∣s,a)≥=0∀s,s′∈S,a∈A(s),r∈R \begin{aligned} & p(s', r | s, a) = \text{Prob}(S_{t+1}=s', R_{t+1}=r | S_{t} = s, A_{t} = 1) \\ \text{ where } \quad & \sum_{s' \in \mathcal{S}} \sum_{R \in \mathcal{R}} p(s', r | s, a) = 1 \quad \forall s \in \mathcal{S}, a \in \mathcal{A}(S) \\ \text{ and } \quad & p(s', r | s, a) \ge = 0 \quad \forall s, s' \in \mathcal{S}, a \in \mathcal{A}(s), r \in \mathcal{R} \end{aligned} where  and ​p(s′,r∣s,a)=Prob(St+1​=s′,Rt+1​=r∣St​=s,At​=1)s′∈S∑​R∈R∑​p(s′,r∣s,a)=1∀s∈S,a∈A(S)p(s′,r∣s,a)≥=0∀s,s′∈S,a∈A(s),r∈R​

children.value: The goal of TD learning is to find an accurate approximation

children.html: Q(s,a)Q(s, a)Q(s,a)

children.value: Q(s, a) \approx q^*(s, a) \; \forall s, a)
children.html: Q(s,a)≈q∗(s,a)  ∀s,a)Q(s, a) \approx q^*(s, a) \; \forall s, a)Q(s,a)≈q∗(s,a)∀s,a)

children.value: There are many RL algorithms that seek to do this
The Bellman equaition for our approximation

Q(s,a)=E[R′+βmax⁡a′Q(s′,a′)∣s,a]Q(s,a) = E[R' + \beta \max_{a'} Q(s', a') | s,a]Q(s,a)=E[R′+βa′max​Q(s′,a′)∣s,a]

children.value: because this isn’t evaluating full Bellman

children.html: Q(St,At)≈Rt+1+βQ(St+1,At+1)Q(S_t,A_t) \approx R_{t+1} + \beta Q(S_{t+1}, A_{t+1})Q(St​,At​)≈Rt+1​+βQ(St+1​,At+1​)

children.value: The difference between the left and right and sides is known as a temporal difference:
TD(0)(Q) \equiv R_{t+1} + \beta Q(S_{t+1}, A_{t+1}) - Q(S_t, A_t)
children.html: TD(0)(Q)≡Rt+1+βQ(St+1,At+1)−Q(St,At)TD(0)(Q) \equiv R_{t+1} + \beta Q(S_{t+1}, A_{t+1}) - Q(S_t, A_t)TD(0)(Q)≡Rt+1​+βQ(St+1​,At+1​)−Q(St​,At​)

children.value: There are extensions to the temporal difference that allow for multiple time periods. The 0 in

children.html: TD(0)TD(0)TD(0)

children.html: TD(0)(Qt)TD(0)(Q_t)TD(0)(Qt​)

Qt+1(St,At)=Qt(St,At)+αTD(0)(Qt)=Qt(St,At)+α[Rt+1+βQt(St+1,At+1)−Qt(St,At)] \begin{aligned} Q_{t+1}(S_t, A_t) &= Q_t(S_t, A_t) + \alpha TD(0)(Q_t) \\ &= Q_t(S_t, A_t) + \alpha \left[R_{t+1} + \beta Q_t(S_{t+1}, A_{t+1}) - Q_t(S_t, A_t) \right] \end{aligned}Qt+1​(St​,At​)​=Qt​(St​,At​)+αTD(0)(Qt​)=Qt​(St​,At​)+α[Rt+1​+βQt​(St+1​,At+1​)−Qt​(St​,At​)]​

children.value: The Sarsa algorithm applies the update rule we just described
The algorithm is summarized by Barto and Sutton as follows (section 6.4)

from collections import defaultdict
import random

import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
In a separate video we implemented the dice game farkle
We’ll re-use that code as an environment for
For a review of farkle, see video
Today we’ll approach it like the RL algorihtm will:
A stochastic environment that sends states, a list of possible actions, and rewards
specialize based on rules of game
Let’s wrap farkle code into environment
step(s: State, a: Action) -> Tuple[State, Reward]
We need to create an env, then pass it to sarsa
We’ll also define a helper function to play a game for us

env = FarkleEnv()
sarsa = Sarsa(env, epsilon=0.9, alpha=0.6)

scores = [h[0].scores for h in env._history]
plt.plot(scores)
plt.legend(["sarsa", "random"])

from farkle import HumanFarklePlayer
env_human = FarkleEnv(opponent=HumanFarklePlayer(name="Spencer"), points_to_win=2000)
sarsa_human = Sarsa(env_human)
Great! Our algorithm can play Farkle
games to learn how to play well
Let’s let it play many more games to build up some intelligence

%%time

def play_many_games(N):
    terminal_states = []
    print_skip = N // 10
    for i in range(N):
        play_game(sarsa)
        terminal_states.append(sarsa.s)
        if i % print_skip == 0:
            print(f"Done with {i}/{N} (len(Q) = {len(sarsa.Q.Q)})")
    return terminal_states

# WARNING: this takes a *long time* and requires a lot of ram!
# Only use on a computer with at least 32 GB ram
# There are ways we could optimize this... such as only including
# final score in `terminal_states` and dropping things like current_round
# from the state
sarsa_history = play_many_games(5000)

children.value: Let’s analyze the history and see if the algorithm learned with experience

won = np.array([s.scores[0] > s.scores[1] for s in sarsa_history])
game_idx = np.arange(len(won))

fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(10, 6))
ax.plot(game_idx, won.cumsum())
ax.plot(game_idx, 0.5 * game_idx)
plt.legend(["sarsa", "E[random agent]"])
